posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked:
I was able in the past to set up an NT server for the vision server that processes our vision system. The change to the NT tables seems to not let me set up this connection any more. I tired the new NT client but I don’t seem to make the connection to the NT table. Any Idea how to do this now?

This is the way I did it before:

Now I only have the the client name as the only input.

Any help with setting this up would be appreciated. I can write something that will dump the vision data to the roboRIO but it was easy for everyone to use the NT tables int he past.

posts.name: Bill
posts.cooked: You should try switching your code to python, it makes network tables a lot easier to use.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Looking inside the NT Client vi, it’s getting the IP address from the DriverStation, assuming that the driver station is running on the same computer. That should work for dashboards, but not if you wanted it on a coprocessor. The C code that it’s calling has additional methods for connecting to a team number (SetServerTeam) or a host/ip address (SetServer)

You can see more details on what’s expected here: NetworkTables Networking — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

link_counts.title: NetworkTables Networking — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked: Thanks for the ideas. Moving to python is not an option. All of the rest of the code is done in LabVIEW so it would not really fix a problem. We just made our own TCP client and server to pass the data now. The NT tables were just easier.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked: I had looked at this before. They removed all access to any of this in the new NT tables. The complied everything to a DLL so I do not have access. It is really sad to see how far LabVIEW has fallen in FIRST . There are not even LabVIEW examples any more. When I started with FIRST LabVIEW was being used by around 60% of the teams. Now it is almost non-existent.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
aeastet:

It is really sad to see how far LabVIEW has fallen in FIRST .

I feel compelled to point out the reason for this is that NI did not keep pace with what the community desires were. Your issues above are yet another example of that.

It is indeed saddening to see this option decay as much as it has. I’m not sure there is a reasonable path that will reverse that trend though - you’re unlikely to persuade the army of volunteers contributing to free software to stop that, and start contributing to NI’s for-profit infrastructure.

aeastet:

Moving to python is not an option.

In-season, there are reasons I might buy this is the right answer.

But, for reasons you self-identified above, I would argue it’s wise to forge a plan that move to a better-supported option.

Offseason is a great time to form, vet, and execute such a plan.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
aeastet:

The complied everything to a DLL so I do not have access.

I’ll admit I haven’t used LabVIEW in a long time, and I’ve never done it, but LabVIEW can call DLLs, and the page I linked above identifies the functions.

The support people on the NI FRC forums are much more likely to be able to help with that then anyone on chiefdelphi, I suspect.

The DLL is a wrapper of the WPILib Network Tables implementation to remove maintenance burden of maintaining a separate implementation.

posts.name: Jim simpson
posts.cooked:
“is that NI did not keep pace with what the community desires were”

While I don’t know about NI, LabVIEW pretty much has the FULL capability of WPILIB.   See here. jsimpso81 (Jim S.) · GitHub (I’m not with NI and I’m only one person…)     I’d be happy to have helpers … I know the lifetime may be short.

However there is still a valid case to have a FBD (functional block diagram) editor for the new control system.  (Not blocky or whatever is being proposed.)   FBD help turn a programming task into an engineering task.  I want to teach control system theory and not programming languages.  (Fortunately I’ve done a lot of both, but I only have so much time with the students, and they only have so much time.)

I have a design in my head for a FBD editor, but won’t really give this a lot of thought until after the season.  It would be flexible, expandable, and configuration/database driven to easily conform to library changes, and additions.

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked: You let me know how I can help and I will definitely help out. I appreciate all the work you have done to allow teams that use LabVIEW to still have access to these tools. Look me up when you have time after the season. We are pretty busy with our season as well. I have a vision system I would love to show you.

posts.name: Jim simpson
posts.cooked:
I was able to create a standalone NT client VI.   The attached project ZIP file has this VI, an IsConnected VI, and a sample program that uses these.  It works without a driver station or dashboard.  It works interactively or as a compiled EXE file.

image 674×503 19.8 KB

image 674×503 19.8 KB

image 674×503 19.8 KB

NT_CLIENT.zip (25.9 KB)

image 644×628 7.69 KB

image 644×628 7.69 KB

image 644×628 7.69 KB

posts.name: aeastet
posts.cooked: Thank you for taking the time to build this. I will test it tonight when I am working with the team. It will save some time so I do not have to rebuild some of the other functions I had built into my code before.

posts.name: Jim simpson
posts.cooked: Here is an updated project.   The functionality is the same.   I cleaned up the VIs and added documentation to them (Ctrl-H).   I also added the enable logging VI so the NT WPI logging function can be turned off or on.  (This appears to need to be done on both the clients and server.) NT_CLIENT_R1.zip (24.6 KB)
